ygData.subject: WORM
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Mr. Kubin.  thank you for the mail on how to get rid of this worm, it is unfortunate the situation you find youself in however one needs to be careful.
ygData.messageBody:
Hello Mr. Kubin. thank you for the mail on how to get rid of this worm, it
is unfortunate the situation you find youself in however one needs to be
careful. Hopefully it was a learning experience for your child.. no major
harm done. Christie is a bitch looks like to me.. no hard feelings thanx
for the cure :P


-----Original Message-----
From: Richard Kubin <rkubin@...>
To: EQ_spell_research@onelist.com <EQ_spell_research@onelist.com>
Date: Sunday, May 16, 1999 7:58 PM
Subject: Re: [EQ_spell_research] word of possession


>From: Richard Kubin <rkubin@...>
>
>EQ_spell_research mail list recipients:
>
>I am copying you on a message I have sent to "cristie". My sons and I
apologize to anyone who may have received
>the happy99.exe worm from this account. They were merely unwitting
participants, having received it from someone
>else. Please check your C:WINDOWS\SYSTEM\ directory for a file named
SKA.EXE or alternatively do a file search
>for happy99.exe. If these exist, then follow the directions below to get
rid of it.
>
>Regards,
>Richard Kubin & Sons
>
>Cristie:
>
>Excuse me. I am not sure who you are, but you certainly do not possess
many
>manners, either Internet or otherwise. This account belongs to me, but is
used
>primarily by my two sons, aged 12 and 14. They are primarily using it for
>playing games (Everquest mostly) as well as for game info and trading magic
>cards. They had no idea that this computer was infected with the worm
>happy99.exe. After they read your first nasty email, they immediately told
me-
>having scanned prior emails, I was able to deduce that one of them had
received
>it on Mar.12 from some other unwitting soul and being a somewhat naive
user, he
>had opened it, thereby infecting this computer.
>
>What any polite person would do upon receiving something like the
happy99.exe
>worm in an email attachment would be to inform the sender of their
infection.
>It is obvious that you know very little about this type of problem (it is
>technically a worm, not a virus). It took me about five minutes to find
out
>about this worm (doing a yahoo search) and another five minutes to get rid
of
>it.
>
>In the future, I would hope that you show a little more respect for your
fellow
>users and rather than making threats, help try to solve the problem. Try
to
>remember that some users are still somewhat young and naive when it comes
to
>computer and internet use and we should try to help where we can. I have
made
>sure that my sons now understand more about internet security and the
dangers
>of viruses etc. A good rule of thumb is never to open any attachments
unless
>you are absolutely sure of the source.
>
>The following link provides information on what the happy99.exe worm is and
how
>to get rid of it:
>http://www.symantec.com/avcenter/venc/data/happy99.worm.html
>
>It is very straight forward and I include instructions here for your
benefit:
>
>VirusName: Happy99.Worm
>Aliases: Trojan.Happy99, I-Worm.Happy
>Likelihood: Common
>Region Reported: World Wide
>Characteristics: Trojan Horse, Worm
>Description:
> This is a worm program, NOT a virus. This program has reportedly been
received
>through email
>spamming and USENET newsgroup posting. The file is usually named
HAPPY99.EXE in
>the email or article attachment. When being executed, the program also
opens a
>window entitled "Happy New Year 1999 !!" showing a firework display to
disguise
>its other actions. The program copies itself as SKA.EXE and extracts a DLL
that
>it carries as SKA.DLL into WINDOWS\SYSTEM directory. It also modifies
>WSOCK32.DLL in WINDOWS\SYSTEM directory and copies the original WSOCK32.DLL
>into WSOCK32.SKA. WSOCK32.DLL handles internet-connectivity in Windows 95
and
>98. The modification to WSOCK32.DLL allows the worm routine to be triggered
>when a connect or send activity is detected. When such online activity
occurs,
>the modified code loads the worm's SKA.DLL. This SKA.DLL creates a new
email or
>a new article with UUENCODED HAPPY99.EXE inserted into the email or
article. It
>then sends this email or posts this article. If WSOCK32.DLL is in use when
the
>worm tries to modify it (i.e. a user is online), the worm adds a registry
>entry:
>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce=SKA.EX
E
>The registry entry loads the worm the next time Windows start.
>
>Removing the worm manually:
>
>1.delete WINDOWS\SYSTEM\SKA.EXE
>2.delete WINDOWS\SYSTEM\SKA.DLL
>3. in WINDOWS\SYSTEM\ directory, rename WSOCK32.DLL to WSOCK32.BAK
>4. in WINDOWS\SYSTEM\ directory, rename WSOCK32.SKA to WSOCK32.DLL
>5.delete the downloaded file, usually named HAPPY99.EXE
>
>Windows prevents you to do step #3 and #4 above if the machine is still
>connected to the Internet. The file "windows\system\wsock32.dll" is used
>whenever the machine is connected to Internet (i.e. through dial-up or LAN
>connection).
>
>Sincerely,
>
>Richard Kubin
>---------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------
>
>
>
>Cristie wrote:
>
>> From: Cristie <cristie@...>
>>
>> Who the HELL do you think you are sending virus executables out to people
>> on a mailing list. I have written to your isp about this matter and I am
>> certain they will take action on it. Spreading viruses is a felony. You
>> don't deserve to have an internet account with any isp in my humble
opinion.
>>
>> At 09:01 AM 5/16/99 -0400, you wrote:
>> >From: Richard Kubin <rkubin@...>
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >

>> >Join the "Star Wars" craze at ONElist.

>> >research. Please keep the emails on topic.
>>

>> http://www.onelist.com
>> ...ONElist IS the place where the world talks!
>> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>> This list is intended for the trade of Spell components for spell
research. Please keep the emails on topic.
>
>
>
>
>------------------------------------------------------------------------
>Are you hogging all the fun?
>http://www.onelist.com
>Friends tell friends about ONElist!
>------------------------------------------------------------------------
>This list is intended for the trade of Spell components for spell research.
Please keep the emails on topic.
